--- title: Syntax aliases: - basics.html - intro_intro.html author: Marie-Hélène Burle --- :::{.def} First, let's cover some basics of the Python syntax. ::: ## Commands Short commands are usually written one per line: ::: {#5f0745cc .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} a = 2.0 print(a) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 2.0 ``` ::: ::: but you can write multiple commands on the same line with the semi-colon separator: ::: {#b945f57c .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} a = 2.0; print(a) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 2.0 ``` ::: ::: :::{.notenoit} In a Python shell or when using Jupyter, you can omit the `print` function if you want to return a result directly (this is not true in [functions definitions](intro_functions)). So the above could be run as: ::: {#1c9c5d46 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} a = 2.0 a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ``` 2.0 ``` ::: ::: and ::: {#5c28816f .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} a = 2.0; a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` 2.0 ``` ::: ::: Be careful though that if you are running a script (i.e. you write this code in a text file with a `.py` extension and execute it by running `python .py` in the command line), nothing will get printed with this method and you have to explicitly use the `print` function. ::: Some commands (e.g. function definitions, for loops, if else statements) span over multiple lines. The first line starts normally, but subsequent lines are indented to mark that they are part of the same command. **This indentation—one tab or a series of spaces (often 4 spaces, but the number can be customized in many IDEs)—has a syntactic meaning in Python and is not just for human readability:** ::: {#77e4b6a9 .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Incorrect code for i in [1, 2]: print(i) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
  Cell In[5], line 3
    print(i)
    ^
IndentationError: expected an indented block after 'for' statement on line 2
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#2a12eff9 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Correct code for i in [1, 2]: print(i) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 2 ``` ::: ::: :::{.note} IDEs and good text editors indent code automatically. ::: ## Comments Comments (snippets of text for human consumption and ignored by the Python interpreter) are marked by the hashtag: ::: {#c1375ab2 .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} # This is a full-line comment print(a) # This is an inline comment ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 2.0 ``` ::: ::: :::{.note} [PEP 8](https://peps.python.org/pep-0008/#maximum-line-length)—the style guide for Python code—suggests a maximum of 72 characters per line for comments. Try to keep comments to the point and spread them over multiple lines if they are too long. ::: ## Basic operations ::: {#4e114567 .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} print(3 + 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 5 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#5ba61a13 .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} print(3.0 - 2.0) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1.0 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#09d3a706 .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} print(10 / 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 5.0 ``` ::: ::: :::{.note} Notice how the result can be of a different type. ::: Variables can be used in operations: ::: {#ca690eed .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} a = 3 print(a + 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 5 ``` ::: ::: `a = a + 10` can be replaced by the more elegant: ::: {#9e5e81ee .cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} a += 10 print(a) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 13 ``` ::: ::: :::{.exo} :::{.yourturn} Your turn: ::: Transform the following code: ```{.python} a = a * 2 print(a) ``` by following these rules: - turn the code as a one-liner, - add a comment to it, - replace the operation with a more elegant form. ::: ## Quotes Pairs of single and double quotes are used to create strings. :::{.note} [PEP 8](https://peps.python.org/pep-0008/#maximum-line-length) does not recommend one style over the other. It does suggest however that once you have chosen a style, you stick to it to make scripts consistent. ::: ::: {#7624deb9 .cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} "This is a string." ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ``` 'This is a string.' ``` ::: ::: ::: {#29960aee .cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} type("This is a string.") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ``` str ``` ::: ::: ::: {#1c50f95a .cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} 'This is also a string.' ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ``` 'This is also a string.' ``` ::: ::: ::: {#c0e10ed8 .cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} type('This is also a string.') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ``` str ``` ::: ::: Apostrophes and textual quotes interfere with Python quotes. In these cases, use the opposite style to avoid any problem: ::: {#8a7b2161 .cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} # This doesn't work 'This string isn't easy' ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
  Cell In[17], line 2
    'This string isn't easy'
                           ^
SyntaxError: unterminated string literal (detected at line 2)
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#8ddfee4b .cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} # This is good "This string isn't easy" ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ``` "This string isn't easy" ``` ::: ::: ::: {#b790b86a .cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} # This doesn't work "He said: "this is a problem."" ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
  Cell In[19], line 2
    "He said: "this is a problem.""
               ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#0d98eefc .cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} # This is good 'He said: "this is a problem."' ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=20} ``` 'He said: "this is a problem."' ``` ::: ::: Sometimes, neither option works and you have to escape some of the quotes with `\`: ::: {#251dc566 .cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} # This doesn't work "He said: "this string isn't easy"" ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
  Cell In[21], line 2
    "He said: "this string isn't easy""
                              ^
SyntaxError: unterminated string literal (detected at line 2)
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#7d82ba2c .cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} # This doesn't work either 'He said: "this string isn't easy"' ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
  Cell In[22], line 2
    'He said: "this string isn't easy"'
                                     ^
SyntaxError: unterminated string literal (detected at line 2)
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#494f4405 .cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} # You can use double quotes and escape double quotes in the string "He said: \"this string isn't easy\"" ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ``` 'He said: "this string isn\'t easy"' ``` ::: ::: ::: {#7a25fb46 .cell execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Or you can use single quotes and escape single quotes in the string 'He said: "this string isn\'t easy"' ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=24} ``` 'He said: "this string isn\'t easy"' ``` ::: :::
